verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Jonah a second time, saying,
verses.comment: God's persistence in calling Jonah mirrors how God continues to call His servants despite failure, emphasizing His mercy and patience. The repetition recalls other prophets receiving renewed calls.

verses.text: "Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and proclaim to it the message that I tell you."
verses.comment: Nineveh was a notoriously pagan city, yet God shows concern for all nations, prefiguring the expansion of salvation beyond Israel. The command to proclaim signifies the prophetic office and the obedience required of God's messengers.

verses.text: So Jonah arose and went to Nineveh, according to the word of the LORD. Now Nineveh was an exceedingly great city, a three days' journey in breadth.
verses.comment: Jonah's obedience contrasts his earlier flight, symbolizing repentance and return to God's will. Nineveh's size represents the extent of its influence and its need for conversion—foreshadowing the universal offer of God's mercy.

verses.text: Jonah began to go into the city, about a day's journey, and he called out, "Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown!"
verses.comment: Forty days suggests a period of testing or repentance (see Matthew 4:2), echoing Israel’s forty years in the wilderness and Jesus’ forty days of fasting. The warning presents God’s justice but also allows the possibility of mercy if the people repent.

verses.text: And the people of Nineveh believed God. They called for a fast and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them to the least.
verses.comment: Collective repentance, shown by fasting and sackcloth, reflects true contrition. From the highest to the lowest, all are called to forgiveness—anticipating the sacramental confession and communal penance found in the Church.

verses.text: When the news reached the king of Nineveh, he arose from his throne, removed his robe, covered himself with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.
verses.comment: The king’s humility before God exemplifies leadership leading by example in repentance. Removal of royal attire for sackcloth points to the abandonment of earthly honors in favor of God’s grace.

verses.text: He issued a proclamation and published it throughout Nineveh: 'By the decree of the king and his nobles, neither man nor beast, herd nor flock, shall taste anything. They shall not eat nor drink water.'
verses.comment: Even animals are included in the fast, signifying a total, communal turning to God. The unity in penance recalls the importance of corporate expressions of faith, which would later be seen in liturgical traditions.

verses.text: But let both man and beast be covered with sackcloth, and let them cry forcefully to God. Let everyone turn from his evil way and from the violence that is in his hands.
verses.comment: The demand for heartfelt repentance (not just outward acts) affirms the necessity of both publicly expressed and interior conversion, preparing for future understandings of sacramental penance.

verses.text: Who knows? God may turn and relent and turn away from his fierce anger, so that we may not perish."
verses.comment: Hope in God's mercy is a recurring biblical theme—repentance can move God to show compassion, demonstrating the interplay of divine justice and mercy foundational to Christian theology.

verses.text: And God saw what they did, how they turned from their evil way. And God relented from the disaster which he had threatened to bring upon them, and he did not do it.
verses.comment: True conversion touches the heart of God, revealing that sincere repentance is effective. Jesus referenced the repentance of Nineveh (Matthew 12:41) as a model, pointing to the power of penance and the necessity of responding when called to conversion.
